title: Buzz: The Morning After Reality Check
plot_outline: Buzz faces a typical day that goes from bad to worse when temptation proves irresistible. What starts as a simple attempt to get their prescription filled becomes a meditation on the system is rigged as Buzz encounters the usual cast of neighborhood characters and discovers that even small victories come with a price.

scenes.title: Rock Bottom Has a Basement
scenes.action: Buzz begins their day with the usual routine of avoiding responsibility and managing expectations. The catalyst for today's adventure presents itself in the form of running out of their vice of choice. Despite every instinct screaming "don't get involved," circumstances and poor judgment combine to draw Buzz into the situation.

dialogue.speaker: Buzz
dialogue.line: I'm too drunk for this, but not drunk enough.
dialogue.tone: slurred optimism fighting against bitter reality
dialogue.subtext: desperately wants to be proven wrong about people

dialogue.speaker: Dumbo
dialogue.line: Can we solve this with minimal effort on my part?
dialogue.tone: defeated resignation with occasional flashes of frustrated energy
dialogue.subtext: revealing more about their pain than intended

dialogue.speaker: Scrapz
dialogue.line: Trust me, it gets worse from here.
dialogue.tone: sharp cynicism barely masking deeper hurt
dialogue.subtext: revealing more about their pain than intended

dialogue.speaker: Buzz
dialogue.line: I'm gonna need something stronger than beer.
dialogue.tone: slurred optimism fighting against bitter reality
dialogue.subtext: secretly hoping someone will save them

visual_details.setting_description: A place where life happens to people who've stopped trying to control it

character_appearances.Buzz: cross-eyed, swaying stance, permanent five o'clock shadow, beer bottle collection, stained tank top, flip-flops, showing signs of spiritual emptiness
character_appearances.Dumbo: droopy, bloodshot, crusty pizza slice, stained remote control, empty beer cans, showing signs of psychological wear
character_appearances.Scrapz: torn ear, ragged fur, perpetual scowl, half-smoked cigarette, ash tray, torn leather jacket, showing signs of chronic exhaustion

visual_details.environmental_details: The accumulated weight of poor life choices made manifest
visual_details.mood_lighting: Harsh fluorescent reality cutting through last night's delusions

scenes.title: When Bad Gets Worse
scenes.action: The situation escalates when a misunderstanding escalates out of control. What seemed like a manageable problem reveals itself to be connected to larger issues involving their own psychological damage. Buzz realizes they're in deeper than anticipated and that their usual strategy of "ignore it and hope it goes away" won't work this time.

dialogue.speaker: Buzz
dialogue.line: Why do all my problems start with someone saying my name?
dialogue.tone: slurred optimism fighting against bitter reality
dialogue.subtext: secretly hoping someone will save them

dialogue.speaker: Dumbo
dialogue.line: I'm starting to regret leaving the house.
dialogue.tone: defeated resignation with occasional flashes of frustrated energy
dialogue.subtext: protecting themselves from further disappointment

dialogue.speaker: Buzz
dialogue.line: At least the bar's still open.
dialogue.tone: slurred optimism fighting against bitter reality
dialogue.subtext: testing whether this person can be trusted

character_appearances.Karen the Social Worker: Tired, worn down, but still clinging to whatever dignity remains

scenes.title: Same Shit, Different Day
scenes.action: The episode concludes with Buzz having learned nothing from their experience but somehow finding themselves in a slightly different variation of the same situation they started in. Victory is redefined as "not making things significantly worse," and the audience is reminded that some problems don't get solvedâ€”they just get replaced with new problems.

dialogue.speaker: Karen the Social Worker
dialogue.line: Well, this should be interesting.
dialogue.tone: weary sarcasm
dialogue.subtext: desperately wants to be proven wrong about people

dialogue.speaker: Dumbo
dialogue.line: I'm starting to regret leaving the house.
dialogue.tone: defeated resignation with occasional flashes of frustrated energy
dialogue.subtext: secretly hoping someone will save them

dialogue.line: Trust me, it gets worse from here.
dialogue.tone: sharp cynicism barely masking deeper hurt
dialogue.subtext: protecting themselves from further disappointment

dialogue.line: Why does this always happen?
dialogue.tone: weary sarcasm
dialogue.subtext: testing whether this person can be trusted

dialogue.speaker: Scrapz
dialogue.line: Next time, count me out.
dialogue.tone: sharp cynicism barely masking deeper hurt
dialogue.subtext: revealing more about their pain than intended
